segments.text: I guess we're all right there.
Transcribers might not appreciate it quite so much.
I have to keep a minute by minute account because the tape doesn't ring like it's supposed to.
Tell me how you developed your interest in oceanography.
My interest in oceanography came about in a rather incidental way, I think.
But it's a rather incidental thing.
I was in the Navy in the Second World War.
And I was also in the process of studying for my degree in physics at that time, before the Second World War.
And I went back and completed my degree in physics after the Second World War and kind of got into geophysics.
and the Earth's magnetic field.
And in fact, I got into some of the early shielding problems for nuclear-powered submarines.
And just one thing and another, I kind of slipped into the field of oceanography that way.
I wanted to work around New York, and I found this unique opportunity to work at the Lamont-Darty Geological Observatory outside of New York in 1960.
So I'm not one of the oldest people around in oceanography.
It's only been 17 years now.
I was trained as a physicist.
And I was interested in geophysics in the sense of large-scale phenomena.
And of course, the oceans do occupy 70% of the Earth.
And you've got to know what's under the oceans if you really want to understand the Earth.
So I kind of got into it that way, I guess.
But that's kind of an oblique way to get into the field.
Well, it may have been sort of typical in the 50s and 60s in that sense.
Where did you do your undergraduate work?
I went to Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge and got my, I almost got my bachelor's there when I went into the Navy.
And then I came back and finished up my bachelor's and got my master's also there.
My bachelor's in 1947, my master's in 1948.
And then went to New York University and got a degree in physics.
Have you all along been inclined towards physics?
That it's something you've developed as an undergraduate at LSU, or just?
Yeah.
No, ever since, I can trace the origin of my interest in physics very carefully as well from my high school days.
My first course in physics, ever since then, I was sold on physics.
And in fact, I've kind of specialized in the Earth's magnetic field and geomagnetism.
I've had that as kind of a love for a long time, too.
So these two things kind of pointed me toward geophysics and pointed me toward the oceans, I guess.
Well, the reason I was asking is physics becomes sort of the infield in oceanography beginning, oh, 56, 57, 58.
You see more of your people drawn towards physics, but you precede that.
Was there anybody at NYU whom?
you should say, had particular influence on you towards physics and oceanography?
No, it wasn't.
My career has been rather checkered.
At NYU, I was studying cosmic rays and things related to cosmic rays and got interested in the large-scale phenomena.
I suppose that's kind of a geophysics.
It's not oriented toward the marine side, but it's geophysics as well.
And from there, I...
You know, when you get your degree in physics, you're really rather well equipped to do any number of things.
I went into teaching overseas and traveling a bit and then worked with General Dynamics Corporation for a few years and got into this propulsion, nuclear propulsion thing with them.
Nuclear propulsion was just becoming feasible in those days and got into the propulsion of submarines and from there got into marine work.
Okay.
Now, when you begin to move into submarines, where do you go to work?
You don't stay with General Dynamics?
No.
The thing I got into with submarines was how you find them in the oceans, which was a very important thing.
And one of the ways you find them is by measuring small magnetic effects.
And so I got started studying the background magnetic effects in the ocean, whether the spatially varying and the time varying magnetic anomalies you have in the ocean.
and found out that those, in fact, could tell you a great deal about the Earth and had never been studied before at all adequately.
And so when I went to Lamont, I studied the magnetic anomalies.
How long were you at Lamont?
I was at Lamont from 1960 to 1967, seven years.
And I was on the research staff there.
After that, I was two years at Hudson Laboratories, another laboratory of Columbia University, which has interesting history.
And I came here to Woods Hole in 1969.
OK, this period between roughly 1667, while you're involved at Lamont, what exactly were you doing there?
Lamont didn't have in those days, and doesn't really now, didn't have a well-defined
departmental structure.
But they had small groups of people that worked together.
And I suppose my position was in charge of the marine magnetic work.
And that occupied about half my time.
And we would put magnetometers on ships at sea and send them around the world, and aircraft and other vessels.
The other half my time was on studying the time variations of the Earth's magnetic field.
And we put instruments in many parts
the United States and South America as well, studying time variations.
Time variation is primarily an ionospheric phenomenon.
It's caused by a change in the ionosphere.
So I had the best of two possible worlds, the early days of satellites and new thrust into space, and the very interesting days in oceanography.
And we were getting marine geophysical phenomena that had some very important meanings.
But is it not correct?
Now, I can be corrected, but weren't you one of the first people to begin to correlate this idea of space and ocean?
We were one of the first, yes.
There were several, two or three places at those days that were into this business.
We had more data than other people.
We had data from more different parts of the world, and so our strong point was...
we could correlate them in many different parts of the world.
And it turned out that was a very significant thing in those days.
The theory of seafloor spreading is primarily based upon magnetic anomalies in the ocean, as you may know.
And so we had a lot of the data to prove the theory of seafloor spreading.
When did you first become interested in seafloor spreading?
Well, I don't know.
I don't know the exact calendar date, but I know the time in the development of science when it happened.

It was about 1965, and it was when we first got some data from the Rike Janus Ridge south of Iceland, the middle of the Atlantic south of Iceland, data that was difficult to interpret in any way except in terms of the sea floor spreading theory.
Then we got, quite by chance, we were also getting data on the diametrically opposite side of the Earth in the South Pacific.
And it told the same story.

So when we had these data quite far apart that could be interpreted in exactly the same way, as a matter of fact, the magnetic anomalies in one place were just like they were in the other, except they were stretched out by a factor of about four.
We interpreted it exactly the same way.
We were convinced, and I think people in many other parts of the world were convinced that there was a lot to the seafloor spreading business.
And that was about 1965.
Well, what seemed to be the general reaction of the scientific community when this data begins to come out on seafloor spreading in 65, 66?
Well, a disbelief, I think, not that they

They disbelieve the data, but to have such a simple and revolutionary interpretation of it, and I say revolutionary even though it had been suggested before, but still, it's hard to believe that the Earth is behaving in this way.
So you've got radio skepticism, as you still do today in many places, and this is very understandable because it's such a,

If you're in the field and realize what it was like before, where you're trying to explain things in quite a different way, and then you come along with a simplified, all-encompassing theory like this, it really is quite profound.
It's very basic.
It means a lot to the people who were in it.
And they were all profoundly impressed with it all.
And it means a lot to the science, the way you do your science.
Who else was involved in seafloor spreading besides yourself?
Well, there were quite a few people involved in different aspects of it.
Just on the magnetic side of it, for example, there were three institutions that had a great deal of more data than anybody else and were probably more active.
There was the Lamont Group, of which I was a part,
There was a Scripps group at Scripps that Victor Wauquiez, Raff, Mason were involved in.
There was a group at Cambridge University in Britain that Drummond Matthews and Fred Vine and Teddy Bullard and others were involved in.
Those were rather the three centers of most of the marine magnetic activity.
Lamont didn't talk to these other two as much as they talked to themselves.
But eventually, we all talked to each other and got it all straightened out.
But Lamont probably had more data than either of these other two institutions.
So it was very nice that we could interpret it in a useful fashion.
But there were other aspects to sea floor spreading than magnetics.
There were many people involved.
Modern founders of the theory generally thought I was being Hess and Dietz.
Hess isn't alive today, but Bob Dietz certainly is.
But those are the people who promoted the idea probably more.
But the magnetics is the first data that proved it convincingly, I think, and kind of turned everybody's thinking around.
And it was especially important after this magnetic data was
was interpreted to get into the seismic data, where you can make some sense out of all the earthquake zones around the world.
So that fell into place next.
So not all of the data that was available in those days supported the theory of sea floor spreading, and still doesn't today.
But far and away, the majority of it does.
So we had to go back and look at some data rather carefully.
But after all, when you're trying to explain almost everything
geological world with one simple theory, you're bound to find something that doesn't quite mesh.
But those were quite exciting days.
And it's always been my feeling that our age of discovery is not over yet.
Dirty hand.
What do you mean our age of discovery is not over yet?
I mean that we're only now learning how to collect really global data and have the computational facilities to see how different types of data are interrelated.
The motions of the Earth's
Axis and other things, the earthquakes and whatnot and whatnot, probably, and changes in the weather, probably all have some interrelation.
And we don't understand it yet.
But once we do, it'll have a tremendous ramification about being able to control our lives on Earth a lot better and predict what's going to happen and where.
And these kinds of things...
are very likely to come about in your lifetime and mine.
Do you think the computer is the key to this?
I think the computer played an extremely important element in the theory of sea floor spreading, because we could handle oceanfuls of data at one time.
Computers are going to make a difference in the future as well.
I'm not saying that's going to be
We're not going to have a technological discovery.
It's not going to be an age of technology so much.
There's still lots of room for big thinkers.
But that is a tool that you need these days in the computer.
It can do so much that you couldn't do before.
It's quite a revolution all its own.
So we'll see all kinds of things, I'm sure, after we
probably de-emphasize the space program a little more and get into emphasizing our own earth science programs a bit more.
I think some of these things will shake out of the woodwork.
Well, it's a thing I was not sure of.
Was it your work with sea floor spreading that led to drilling in the ocean floor?
Was this where your interest came from in that?
No.
Well, because the institutions I've been associated with have always been a member of the majority's organization, which advises the deep-sea drilling project.
I've always been closely associated with the deep-sea drilling project.

And the last few years, they've had the capability of drilling rather deep holes into the ocean crust, which is something kind of new, and we've been expecting quite important things to come from that, and some of them have.
And the latest thing I've gotten involved in is instrumenting the seafloor, putting special instruments in the seafloor in some of these holes that have been drilled.
And so we're now getting heavily involved in that with seismometers and other instruments that are useful all over the world in the seafloor, telling you something about what's going on down there.
But in a sense, the deep-sea drilling project is another one of these global projects that
provides worldwide data and some very good data.
One has to be very cautious of interpreting analysis of certain of these rocks, where the rock is a very small thing.
And what happens in a particular spot you drill in the ocean may not be happening everywhere in the world.
So you don't want to generalize too quickly.
But we're building up quite a body of data in the deep sea drilling project now.
quite useful.
When did you begin the deep sea drilling project?
Well, I think it actually began in its disguised form back about 1958.
But they weren't using this same ship, the Glomar Challenger.
So they've completed now about 55 cruises.
And they have a 55th cruise now of two months each.
So that turns out to be quite a few years.
nine years, I guess, that they've been drilling around the world.
I've been fortunate to be able to participate in two of these cruises.
And it's been very nice because it's been a truly international project.
I think one of the first ones we've had in the marine area that's truly international.
And working with scientists on their own terms is not where they are an incidental member of a project, but where we are a truly joint work as a
It's been quite a stimulating thing to do.
After all, I think the real aim of the game is intellectual stimulation from all of the science that we do, and satisfaction from the benefits you get out of it to help society, I suppose.
How has international cooperation operated on this project?
Has it been good?
Yes, it has.
It's had its growing pains.
The project
The Deep Sea Drilling Project has been advised by this JOIDES organization.
And the JOIDES is an organization of institutions.
Well, in non-US places, the institutions turn out to be government laboratories frequently.
So we have a mixture of US private, semi-private labs.
and some non-US government laboratories.
So it's been kind of a hodgepodge of types of organizations.
But each one has to justify projects in a slightly different way.
Each one has slightly different goals funded on a different basis.
And it's been a real interesting thing from the scientific management point of view to see how you can manage all of these different groups.
And each one gets his own fair share out of it, puts his own fair share into it.
So that's been, I think, quite good.
There's been a very minimum of political involvement, although those things frequently are around the corner.
But it's worked out quite well, I think.
I hope we have more like it.
You think the new international boundaries will limit
Yes, very much so.
The deep sea drilling project is getting into trouble now.
Several countries couldn't see fit to let them drill in their waters for one reason or another.
And there looks like there might be some other problems in the future in that regard.
So the problems are increasingly frequent now.
So we may have to change our way of operating somewhat to overcome this.
It's true in oceanography in general, of course.
In this institution alone, we've had a large fraction of our plans have been changed because we didn't get permission from certain countries to work in their waters offshore.
I think the DC Drilling Project has been one project that's been very good.
I've been fortunate to be involved in some other projects
fairly large, and I think also made some contribution too.
One of those.

Well, we had a project that started here in 1972 called Project Famous out in the joint US and French cooperative project where we were diving with submersibles into the mid-Atlantic Ridge Rift Valley.
And we made another 50 submersible dives to something like 9,000 feet then.
one summer alone, we've had something like 25 or 30 cruises to the area.
And we were mapping the geological structure on a scale of a few tens of feet.
And that worked out real well.
There was a lot of popularity in the press when it came out in 1974.
Our big diving program was in 1974.
And we've had some very good scientific spinoffs from that.
And some other programs have fallen.
similar diving programs in other areas.
This year, we had a big program in the Galapagos area, the Pacific.
It's been very popular.
And found some hot springs and so forth.
Been very, very good.
So that type of program, that's going to continue for a few years now, sometimes working with the French, sometimes working just with the US.
I think that's the first real step by man
man as a scientist studying the seafloor, working on the seafloor.
And it was a real success, I think.
We're going to see more of it.
We're just learning how to utilize man on the seafloor now.
That's going to be a big thing in the next few years, manned exploration of the seafloor.
Hopefully, we could get the space agents to become as interested in that as they have in the exploration of the planets.
I heard some adverse comment on subversible work.
Several people have said they don't think that in terms of cost, you get your money's worth.
What's your reaction to that?
Well, this was a very common reaction when this project got started.
And so we tried to be extremely careful in setting up the project so that it would be cost effective.
And I must say, the comments of that nature
have almost disappeared now.
There are a few around.
When you look back in hindsight, there are a number of things in science that really have produced nothing.
But they had to be done.
You had to go through that period.
The submersible work was in that category, I think, for a while.
I don't think it is now.
We have so many different tools we bring to bear before you even have the submersibles go down.
The people in the submersible almost know what to expect.
The details, they don't know.
We always say that they should be prepared for small surprises, but not big ones.
If they have a big surprise, they haven't done their homework right.
So we come in and map these areas and know the gross characteristics of them before they go in, for safety reasons and for nothing else.
So when they go down the submersible, they have a very specific chore that has been, in that particular dive mission, has been screened by a group
They know it's a worthwhile mission.
Project Famous costs the US taxpayers about $4 million over a period of four years.
And there are a few people who feel that that was ill-spent.
Most people, I think, now feel it.
We've had over 100 scientific papers come out.
We've had two movies.
We've had books of science fiction and books of fact come out on it.
I think, rather well received.
Very fundamental facts emerged from this that couldn't have been found any other way.
Such as?
Oh, the details of the, of course, this is where the plates are generated, the big plates.
And we now know a great deal more about the emplacement of those plates than we knew before.
Even though we'd been over the area quite thoroughly with surface ships, we just didn't have it all put together.
But we know pretty much now about the
spatial and time episodic activity that occurs there, and how the boundaries migrate with time, and how the volcanism migrates with time, both in the ridge axis and in the fracture zone.
And I don't think we could have gotten that any other way.
Well, you think submersibles then were necessary to prove plate tectonics?
Yes.
Well, to get these details, you couldn't have done it any other way.
I'm not suggesting you rush out and give everybody a submersible.
There's just a few jobs that submersibles can do, and that is one.
I think there are a couple of other jobs a submersible can do, exploring canyons and things of the right size.
And there will be more and more jobs for submersibles.
But right now, without submersible technology, there are a few jobs they can do that are cost-effective.
At least in my book, they are cost-effective.
I think in most people's books, they're cost-effective.
So a lot of things cost more than submersibles these days.
It appears, I have a couple of questions too I want to ask very quickly that I was going to ask you later on.
I'll put on tape now.
It appears, though, however, that funding for oceanography is going to drop.
It doesn't look like it's going to increase.
And it also looks as if, because of international treaties, oceanography is going to have to move closer to shore than away from shore.
Well, take it one at a time, OK?
I have been in, as I mentioned before, I've only been in the oceanography game now seriously about 17 years.
And many other people have greater perspective, I suppose.
And you look for long-term trends, and you try to see what the meaning of those are, what causes them.
And there have been a few indicators, I think, that mark changes in the approach to oceanography.
A very important thing has been the Navy's change in its attitude toward marine research.
And here a few years ago, five to eight years ago, the Navy did change its attitude quite a bit.
It essentially moved the research into its own laboratories instead of sponsoring so much outside because it felt like that would be more applied to their needs.
But it did affect marine research.
You know, the US Navy's research in their late 50s and early 60s is one of the things that helped us prove the theory of sea flow spreading.
Particularly their magnetic work, all that was supported by the Navy in this country.
The Navy did many things like that.
Now they're kind of pulling out in many ways as far as purely academic research goes.
And the National Science Foundation and other agencies are not picking up the ball quite as fast as the Navy's dropping it.
Because they're all looking for applied things.
They're not emphasizing as much basic science as they did in those days.
So there's some of that.
I don't think one ought to panic at these kinds of things.
I think the pendulum will swing back.
I think there's just natural fluctuations.
The American public has to try the applied side, then they'll try the basic side, and they'll just swing back and forth a bit.
I don't think we ever ought to go overboard in the research business.
After all, research is a rare luxury for those of us who engage in it.
You can't expect to supply research funds for half the United States.
You really can't.
So I think it should be for a few people.
And you shouldn't expect too quick a turnaround on it.
And for that reason, people shouldn't expect a lot of money to be poured into it.
I mean, you just have to not ask for too much.
But it is a bit unfortunate that the Navy didn't support research as much as it did, I think.
